awd_titl_txt: SRS-RN: The Continuum of Urbanity as an Organizing Concept to Promote Sustainability in the Mid-Hudson Region
awd_abstract_narration:
Learning how people can sustainably live in a world where urban areas are increasing is critical to support happy and healthy communities. However, it is poorly understood how connections between urban and rural areas, past human actions, new pressures like COVID-19, and climate change will affect the sustainability of these regions. The Hudson Valley presents a unique opportunity to understand how to improve sustainability. The valley is close to a large urban center where people are moving to rural areas from urban centers. Many of the valley’s rural and wild ecosystems are still intact, making it possible to understand how the migration of people from the urban centers will affect these systems. The project will bring together diverse stakeholders to plan a large-scale research, education, and community engagement program on the sustainability of the Hudson Valley, with results that could also help improve sustainability in other regions of the nation.

This project is guided by an overarching question: “How do changes in connectivity interact with past human actions to create barriers and opportunities for sustainable development, adaptation, and transformation across a continuum of urbanity?” Continuum theory suggests that measurable conditions of livelihood, lifestyle, and regional landscape structure and function interact with the drivers of changing connectivity. The Hudson Valley Region (HVR) includes urban and rural areas from north of New York City to Albany, NY. The HVR is an ideal test case because it is geographically and historically understandable as a system with a long history of urban-rural interactions and increasing connectivity. A future research and stakeholder engagement program that answers the overarching question while helping guide the HVR towards a more sustainable future, will meet four goals: 1) Work outward from the core research team to build an inclusive network of social and economic scientists, ecologists, land change researchers, humanists, and stakeholders representing community groups, environmental and planning non-profits, urban design firms, and government agencies; 2) Collect and analyze existing regional and local sustainability plans to understand current goals at multiple scales across HVR; 3) Facilitate stakeholder interaction and inform joint work with these stakeholders; and 4) Identify the scope of research with stakeholders. The scope of research will be based on (a) co-produced research questions of mutual interest to practitioners, policy makers, communities, and academics; (b) identified focal ecosystems or social-ecological places; (c) appropriately set spatial and temporal scales for each focus; (d) key measurements of regional change and connectivity; and (e) strategies to promote equitable and just engagement with communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As COVID-19 gripped New York City, its usual activity was curtailed. Many people left “the City” for less risky areas. Sixty-five percent more people left NYC in March 2020 than in March 2019. North of New York City, the Mid-Hudson Valley Region (HVR) of New York State experienced population increase. Remote work became common. House prices spiked 10 – 20% more than pre-pandemic levels, while supply sharply declined. Affordability suffered. The Valley’s natural areas were thronged by visitors seeking socially-distanced recreation. The increase in homebound online shoppers helped expand transportation and distribution infrastructure in the Valley.

What was the ecological effect of these pandemic changes? The HVR is a complex mix of urban and rural landscapes, consisting of cities, towns, suburbs, farms, and forests, as well as lakes and tributary streams of the Hudson River. How did land cover change during COVID? Were there changes in the green spaces in the Valley’s small cities and suburbs? Are wetland loss and forest fragmentation affected by the ripple effects from NYC? Are there changes in the region’s urban heat islands? Was water quality or septic load altered? In addition, how these issues interact and how they are affected by changing climate must also be taken into account. NYC has long experienced external shocks, that can influence HVR ecology, for example, the terrorist attacks of 2001 and Superstorm Sandy.

The answers to these questions are not yet available for the region. Consequently, this Sustainable Regional Systems planning project had two aims: 1) Enhance the intellectual foundation for understanding dynamic changes in a highly urbanized but complex region experiencing external shocks; 2) Achieve the broader impacts of identifying data needed to help residents and planners in the HVR to make better decisions in the face of regional changes such as those following shocks from New York City to its south. Providing better regional data supported by appropriately scalable frameworks is likely to enhance sustainability planning.

The project proposes that the ecology of the HVR is intimately connected to official and individual decisions in NYC. However, these ecologically important connections are inadequately studied. In addition, there are complex patterns within the HVR itself, linking cities, suburbs, exurbs, agricultural, and wild patches. The conditions of complexity and connectivity are likely changing rapidly, and therefore require new research and practical networking.

Intellectual Merit

The Hudson Valley Region provides an important case of the ecological function of complex urbanized regions. How connectivity operates at various scales is a grand challenge for sustainability of urban-rural systems worldwide. The project has improved the continuum of urbanity as a conceptual framework to address a globally relevant question: How do changes in connectivity interact with legacy effects to create obstacles and opportunities for sustainable development, adaptation, and transformation given the distant effects of urban systems? 

The continuum is a novel theory to discover indirect and distant influences of cities, suburbs, and exurbs on each other and on non-urban ecosystems. It hypothesizes that the conditions of livelihood, lifestyle, and social-ecological system (SES) structure and function interact with changing connectivity Figure 1). This framework applies at multiple scales, ranging from the HVR region to the urban-rural transitions of its individual cities. This research is broadly applicable given the ongoing global expansion of urban populations and infrastructure, and their influences on extensive regions containing non-urban lands. The project has refined the continuum theory as a tool to measure ecological connections in and among urban regions.

Broader Impacts

The continuum of urbanity also serves as a practical framework to explore how connectivity across the region affects livelihood, lifestyle, and local ecosystems. It can identify both the opportunities and barriers to sustainability encountered by communities, planners, and governments. The HVR contains its own diverse urban, agricultural, and wild lands undergoing trajectories of change influenced by past and present policies and shocks. Hence, planners, decision makers, and residents must be prepared to evaluate a variety of social, ecological, and technological legacies that can interact with their proposed interventions for sustainability and climate adaptation.

The project evaluated a broad collection of the environmentally relevant plans in the HVR to identify new knowledge needs they suggest. The project evaluated the equity and justice implications of a subset of the plans to expose opportunities for improvement. Meetings with professional strategic planners and with community and municipal planers were held to learn and share their environmental and social concerns. The meetings allowed municipal, county, and regional planners to network with each other, and to share data and strategies for solutions. Future needs include enhancing regional environmental data; a knowledge hub to facilitate access and interpretation; improved education on environmental knowledge relevant to planning and policy for both youth and the public in general; the use of social-ecological systems thinking to integrate currently siloed solutions.
